Official Website: http://squidsoft.net
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Humanity has just emerged from the lowest point in its collective history, and
the closest it has been to extinction since the advent of agriculture. By the
year 2304, the Coalition of humans and their alien allies the Jinu has spread
across the stars, and thought themselves powerful. But the Outsiders, an alien
empire occupying vast reaches of Rimward space, proved them wrong. First contact
between the two allies was severed, and suddenly humanity was alone. Then the
Outsiders attacked in force, and human planets and governments fell one by one.
                         It was the apocalypse.
But contrary to the beliefs of many, not all hope was lost. After five years,
a single starship, the Percival Lowell, returned from Rimward space, bringing
with it the means to nullify the Outsiders' greatest weapon. With this, and the
help of many other brave pilots, the occupying Outsiders were driven off human
               worlds and back to where they came from.
 Humanity is now trying to rebuild, and trying to regain what it has lost. The
Outsiders are finished with occupation, and now desire only to see humans
extinct.
New threats and new mysteries seem to appear every day. In the midst of it all,
civilian starships span the stars, maintaining an open threat against any new
       invasion and trying to make a few credits while they're at it.
You too have felt the lure of this; the desire for a unique freedom that most
citizens will never know, the drive to explore, the need to defend your species,
         and yes, greed for the vast wealth that is to be had.
                   It is time to take to the stars.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Welcome to the original and still the most innovative pulp science fiction
multiplayer roleplaying adventure!
Originally opened in its classic form on 19 December 1998! Reopened in its new
iteration on 28 February 2009!
All original work (including setting, non-player characters, design, source
code, all related background material, and all text) located in this game or on
the Squidsoft.net website is copyright (c) Squidsoft.net 1998-2015. Unauthorised
reproduction prohibited.
Warning: Speech in this game is largely uncensored, and sensitive individuals
may find some other players offensive. The staff is ultimately not responsible
for the words and actions of the players.
The last server reset was at Mon Sep 26 07:13:15 2016 UTC
We're on Twitter! @StarConquest for server status notifications and out-of-game
contact!

    * Welcome to Star Conquest! *
[New Earth; Spaceport East]
This part of the spaceport has a fresh new look. Numerous pilot services are
available from the facilities here, including from the new Unreality Programming
office to the south, where a bold green and white banner announces: 'Employment
Opportunities! Apply inside!' Next to it, the spaceport's ship store competes
with a brand new flashing sign reading: 'Ship Sales! Don't be grounded!' Between
them, nearly hidden behind a potted plant is a wide stairway leading downward to
a lower level of the spaceport. A small sign near the stairway reads: Aerial
Fortresses and Supply. Other areas of interest here are the Fund Center to the
northwest, the pawn shop to the north, and the trading center to the northeast.
You see a trash can here.
You can go north, northeast, east, southeast, south, southwest, west, northwest,
and down.
e
[New Earth; Spaceport East]
You can go northeast, east, southeast, south, southwest, and west.

[Starship "William Dove"; Control Room]
You see a sleek metal quantum entanglement communication device, a rattan floor
lamp with a light purple lotus shade (casting a white-colored glow), a wormhole
drive tracer, a dark purple leather captain's chair, a large oval white and
black cloth rug, a rare black EAOSian contoured couch with a hand-made white and
sapphire star quilt on it, Desiree the little black and white spotted CatBot, a
glossy purple ceramic felo chow bowl, a round white rattan coffee table with a

refrigerator, Magellan the arachnoid security robot, and a small white trash bin
here.

ftl acord
"acord" does not match any known sector.
ftl accord
A handful of lonely beacons watch over this area of space, their lights glowing
palely in the dark, surrounded by tendrils of drifting dust and debris.
A planet once existed here, until it was destroyed by the Outsiders. Now only
large chunks of the planet remain, still drifting slowly away from each other,
with clouds of debris filling the sector.
A circular space station dominates this sector, made of darkened metal
reinforced against attack. By the look of it, this is probably the most heavily
armored station in human space, excepting The Torus. This is the heart of the
Accord of Free Worlds.
Via general sector communication, Accord of Free Worlds Command transmits,
"Hello, Shooting Star. Welcome to Accord space."

l
[Accord of Free Worlds; Service Ring]
A large transparisteel window is on the station's port side here, as tall as
both main rings together. The transparisteel is slightly darkened, both
polarized and reinforced with some other material, perhaps even trace
neutronium. The bulkheads and deck are made of a darkened, glossy metal, though
not as dark as the station's exterior. Emergency lights are mounted every three
meters overhead. Light blue trim where the bulkheads meet the deck indicate that
this is the Service Deck.
You can go north, east, and south.

l last core
a temporary space station core module (contributed by Space Explorers Amidst The
Stars)
This is a core module.
This is the basic core of every temporary space station.
It is not attached to anything.

(contributed by Suicide Kings).

attach power to second control
You attach a length of power feed cable to a socket on a basic control center
module (contributed by Suicide Kings).

attach air to last control
You must connect a basic control center module (contributed by Suicide Kings) to
a core module.
attach air to last core
You plug a length of air hose into a nozzle on a temporary space station core
module (contributed by Space Explorers Amidst The Stars), connecting it to a
basic control center module (contributed by Suicide Kings).
(6 seconds roundtime.)
[Notification from Space Explorers Amidst The Stars] A load of salvage has been
received at League Xenological Salvage Processing Debris-Burning Message Beacon
from the two-person medium transport "Money Maker". The organization has earned
1,086,134.14 credits.

core module (contributed by Space Explorers Amidst The Stars), connecting it to
a basic control center module (contributed by Suicide Kings).

attach second control
You can't attach a basic control center module (contributed by Suicide Kings).

I don't understand that.
Try this instead:  combine second control
combine second control
You brace yourself against a basic control center module (contributed by Suicide
Kings), then push it toward a temporary space station core module (contributed
by Space Explorers Amidst The Stars) until it locks into place.

l inserter
an external rift inserter module (contributed by Business Cats)
This is a side module.
This module, when accompanied by a rift accelerator, will push ships without
rift drives into the rift to travel along a matching vector.
It will use 10 power.
It is not attached to anything.

An external rift inserter module (contributed by Business Cats) does not have an
air hose hooked up.

comm last core

Explorers Amidst The Stars) (attached):
--
Unique   attach/hookup <something> to last core                                 
             combine last core
         detach last core

Common   get last core                                                          
             drop/throw last core
         give/hand last core to <something>

l last unmanned
a storage container unmanned pickup module (contributed by Space Invaders)
This is a side module.
This module enables a storage module to be ejected while the station is still
online. The module will then be picked up by an unmanned transport and returned
to a spaceport. Requires a station in communications range.
It will use 10 power.

a storage container unmanned pickup module (contributed by Space Invaders)
This is a side module.
This module enables a storage module to be ejected while the station is still
online. The module will then be picked up by an unmanned transport and returned
to a spaceport. Requires a station in communications range.
It will use 10 power.
It is not attached to anything.

l unmanned
a storage container unmanned pickup module (contributed by Space Invaders)
This is a side module.
This module enables a storage module to be ejected while the station is still
online. The module will then be picked up by an unmanned transport and returned
to a spaceport. Requires a station in communications range.
It will use 10 power.
It is not attached to anything.
Its air intake and power feed are properly hooked up.

Invaders):
--
Unique   attach/hookup <something> to unmanned                                  
             combine unmanned
         detach unmanned
--
Common   get unmanned                                                           
             drop/throw unmanned
         give/hand unmanned to <something>
--

l unmanned
a storage container unmanned pickup module (contributed by Space Invaders)
(attached)
This is a side module.
This module enables a storage module to be ejected while the station is still
online. The module will then be picked up by an unmanned transport and returned
to a spaceport. Requires a station in communications range.
It will use 10 power.
It is attached to the core module.
Its air intake and power feed are properly hooked up.

jumped into the sector.

Zeta 0" has docked with AFW Command (Dock One).

"Hello, Money Maker. Welcome to Accord space."

[Starship "Herding Cats"; Control Room]

launch
The navigation systems are nonfunctional until their power is restored.
power
You grasp a large lever on the control board and push it slowly away from you.
Status lights blink on all around you as faint hums and beeps begin to emanate
from the various starship systems.
launch
You use the ship's radio to ask flight control for launch clearance.
Flight control gives the ship launch clearance.
s
[Starship "Herding Cats"; Main Deck]
You can go north, east, south, west, up, and down.
n

fringe and a comfy neon purple Business Cats floor pillow here.

bay

A low vibration runs through the starship as the module bay door opens.

l battery
a large precharged battery module (contributed by Lily Kaise)
This is a power plant module.
This large battery array manages to match the output of the fusion power plant
and lasts a bit longer.
It will supply 100 power.
It is not attached to anything.
l beacon
a passive sector beacon module (contributed by Pierre-Louis Tremblay-du-Lys)
This is a side module.
This is a low-power beacon which nonetheless manages to have a moderately good
range, at the expense of an active positioning system. Range: 3 light-trade
cycles.
It will use 10 power.
It is not attached to anything.
Its air intake and power feed are properly hooked up.

l
[Starship "Critical Strike"; Control Room]
The control room is the hub of every starship. Large metal conduits protect
thick bundles of wires carrying information from every part of the ship to this
one location. A large transparisteel viewport provides a view out the front of
the ship, but experienced pilots in space will have eyes only for the large
starmap dominating the right side of the room. Standing before the viewport is
the main control board, providing essential functions like the shipwide power
lever and alert status. Secondary control boards can be pulled up and folded
back to provide a working surface, or pulled down from recesses overhead as
needed. Though the room is spacious enough for a few others to sit or stand, the
entire architecture of the room is built around the small space before the
control board and the person who will stand there: the starship's pilot. Lights
overhead indicate that the ship is on yellow alert. Looking through the windows,
you see that the ship is in space.
You see a decoy beacon launcher, a steel plaque engraved with the phrase
"Reminder: This ship is equipped with a sensor dampening array.", a wormhole
drive tracer, a black leather captain's chair, a dark red leather captain's
chair, and a black leather sofa here.
You can go south and out.
pa Remember, if a rapid shows up, gun like your life depends on it.

A pair of odd-colored stars, one green and one blue, mark this curious area of
space. The sensors are picking up odd bits of noise that the ship's computer
insists on trying to convert to audio. Once in a while, something that could
almost sound like a word emerges from a burst of static.
The computer reports that in-sector beacons are transmitting the following:
aKwp[JW7~J{3EHrs.e#=XD-{<jx.1R^pLO(wX]&c
This area of space is within the green belt of the nearest star, but there are
no life-bearing planets here. Instead there is merely an odd cluster of space
stations of unknown origin.
The sensor noise is much worse here, with a constant dark, gutteral snarling
sound emanating from the ship's speakers. It almost sounds like a language, but
it's nothing you've ever heard before, and the ship's computer cannot pinpoint a
source.
[Tactical Communication] Jada Nelson transmits, "Aww ok."
Via general sector communication, a temporary space station transmits, "Hello
pilots, as you travel to the bubble or one of our two asteroid hauling stations,
remember to stay safe, keep a check on your charge and please have EAOS credits
on hand for the tolls."
Via general sector communication, a temporary space station transmits, "Current
riftflow conditions are 2238 light-minutes per second from Galactic
Eastnortheast and Very Slightly Up."

"Detecting vessel 'Critical Strike.' Welcome to The Belt of Orion."

space. The sensors are picking up odd bits of noise that the ship's computer
insists on trying to convert to audio. Once in a while, something that could
almost sound like a word emerges from a burst of static.

This area of space is within the green belt of the nearest star, but there are
no life-bearing planets here. Instead there is merely an odd cluster of space
stations of unknown origin.
The sensor noise is much worse here, with a constant dark, gutteral snarling
sound emanating from the ship's speakers. It almost sounds like a language, but
it's nothing you've ever heard before, and the ship's computer cannot pinpoint a
source.

[Starship "Critical Strike"; Weapons Room One]
Unlike the control room, a starship's weapon room has only one tiny viewport.
The focus of the room is a slightly miniaturized starmap, augmented with
additional spatial relationship information and various status displays. A
streamlined control board sits before the starmap, with prominent indicators for
lock status and weapon readiness. Control boards for the ship's weaponry are off
to either side, to be pulled into place at a moment's notice. Lights overhead
indicate that the ship is on red alert. Looking through the windows, you see
that the ship is in space.
You see a steel plaque engraved with the phrase "Please only use lasers unless
otherwise directed. Thank you." and an overstuffed red chair here.
You can go east.

green
You lift a small plastic cover and press a green button.
You hear a single beep and glance up to see green lights flick on overhead as
the ship enters normal status.
A low hum you had barely noticed until now slowly fades away as weapons are
powered down.

Omega 0" has performed an emergency jump with heavy wormhole drive damage.

to the word MANUAL switches off.

Lily Kaise glides in from the south.
pa cool
You speak into the microphone.
Providence Station shines brightly in the dark, one of the few stations that
bothers to illuminate its outer hull. The gleaming hull of the station is bathed
with bright white floodlights.
kiss lily on lips
You kiss Lily Kaise on the lips.
New Earth rotates through space before you, a startingly verdant planet, colored
in greens and blues with pure white clouds.
move
Via general sector communication, New Earth transmits, "Hello there, Critical
Strike! Welcome to home space!"

wait.

l
[Old Earth; Manhattan Spaceport]
Welcome to Manhattan Spaceport! The entire place seems brand new, the glass
sparkling, the plasteel gleaming. Starships arrive and depart while others sit
on individual pads, rings of lights blinking around them as they are recharged.
Occasionally, the ground vibrates and the low rumble of heavy hydraulics is
heard as a starship is brought up from the underground garage or lowered for
extended parking below. Around the huge landing pad, wide, arched doorways
framed in brushed steel lead to various station services: Repair & Rearm to the
northeast, Supply to the southeast, Station Security to the southwest, and the
Mail Room to the northwest. In addition, a classy lighted sign over one doorway
reads, 'Pilot Lounge.' You can GO into it. There is also a doorway marked
'Liaison Office' that you can also GO into. Over the corridor to the south,
another sign reads 'Spaceport Exit and Express Train.'
The one-person cargo hauler "Tony's Delivery Shuttle", the two-person hardened
asteroid hauler "Asteroid Flyer", the two-person Accord gemini "Endless Melody",
and the five-person A.S.S. tactical platform "William Dove" are landed here.
You see an asteroid-shaped steel trash bin here.
Lillian Hudson, Johann Rowan, and Lily Kaise are standing here.
You can go north, northeast, east, southeast, south, southwest, west, northwest,
and down.
Lillian Hudson takes control of your group.
wave lillian
Lily Kaise waves.
You wave to Lillian Hudson.
The five-person strike gunboat "Shadowsong" is slowly brought in aboard an
automated flatbed, then lowered to the floor.
You follow Lillian Hudson aboard the five-person strike gunboat "Shadowsong".
[Starship "Shadowsong"; Airlock]
Lillian Hudson, Johann Rowan, and Lily Kaise are standing here.
You can go out and enter into the ship.
You follow Lillian Hudson into the ship.
[Starship "Shadowsong"; Control Room]
You see a black leather captain's chair, a bioaugmentation plant in a small pot
labeled "Space Invaders", a decoy beacon launcher, a wormhole drive tracer, and
a crimson plastic box labeled 'THANK YOU!' here.
Lillian Hudson, Johann Rowan, and Lily Kaise are standing here.
You can go south and out.
Johann Rowan nods to you.
Lillian Hudson grasps a large lever on the control board and pushes it slowly
away from her.
Status lights blink on all around you as faint hums and beeps begin to emanate
from the various starship systems.
Johann Rowan nods to Lily Kaise.
Lillian Hudson disbands her group.
Johann Rowan walks south.
Lily Kaise glides south.
s
[Starship "Shadowsong"; Corridor]
Lily Kaise is standing here.
You can go north, east, south, west, up, and down.
u
[Starship "Shadowsong"; Weapons Room Three]
You see a swiveling dark purple leather gunner's chair here.
You can go south and down.
Lily Kaise glides in from below.
Lily Kaise glides south.
Lillian Hudson strides in from below.
Lillian Hudson strides south.
sit chair
You sit down on a swiveling dark purple leather gunner's chair.
Lillian Hudson strides in from the south.
Lillian Hudson strides down.
weapons
Weapons status:
Chaingun turrets: 16 out of 16 functioning.
Chaingun turrets under control of this weapons room: 6 out of 6 functioning.
Torpedo launchers: 3 out of 3 functioning.
Torpedo launchers under control of this weapons room: 1 out of 1 functioning.
Chainguns: 5900 out of 6400 remaining.
  Standard rounds: 5900
Torpedoes: 10 out of 12 remaining.
  Standard torpedoes: 10
1100 out of 1100 combat energy grid remaining.
Weapons are not operational while ship is not in flight.
peer s
You peer south...
[Starship "Shadowsong"; Engineering Room]
The engineering room is much cleaner and sterile than most people expect when
they first board a starship. Though there are some exposed, thick bundles of
wires running here and there, most of the actual workings of the ship are deeper
in its structure. Instead, the room is virtually bare and brightly lit, with one
wall dominated by a large graphical representation of the ship and its
components, alongside current estimates of damage levels. On the right is a
small starmap set into a wall, displaying a bare minimum of information so that
it is not a distraction to the one keeping the ship together. A simple control
board allows the operator to prioritize repairs. Lights overhead indicate that
the ship is on green status. Looking through the windows, you see that the ship
is at Old Earth; Manhattan Spaceport.
You see a large leather chair and an improved temporary wormhole drive here.
Lily Kaise is standing here.
You can go north and south.
Lillian Hudson's voice comes over the loudspeaker and says, "Had to rearm."
Lily Kaise's voice comes over the loudspeaker and says, "Settled."

tra 1 Hello AEU.

ftl accord
A handful of lonely beacons watch over this area of space, their lights glowing
palely in the dark, surrounded by tendrils of drifting dust and debris.
A planet once existed here, until it was destroyed by the Outsiders. Now only
large chunks of the planet remain, still drifting slowly away from each other,
with clouds of debris filling the sector.
A circular space station dominates this sector, made of darkened metal
reinforced against attack. By the look of it, this is probably the most heavily
armored station in human space, excepting The Torus. This is the heart of the
Accord of Free Worlds.

A pair of odd-colored stars, one green and one blue, mark this curious area of
space. The sensors are picking up odd bits of noise that the ship's computer
insists on trying to convert to audio. Once in a while, something that could
almost sound like a word emerges from a burst of static.
The computer reports that in-sector beacons are transmitting the following:
Pb=qgbmz(4OFVd@"m,cY(H}oq+W/&p=E,r7oYLxA
This area of space is within the green belt of the nearest star, but there are
no life-bearing planets here. Instead there is merely an odd cluster of space
stations of unknown origin.
The sensor noise is much worse here, with a constant dark, gutteral snarling
sound emanating from the ship's speakers. It almost sounds like a language, but
it's nothing you've ever heard before, and the ship's computer cannot pinpoint a
source.
Via general sector communication, a temporary space station transmits, "Hello
pilots, as you travel to the bubble or one of our two asteroid hauling stations,
remember to stay safe, keep a check on your charge and please have EAOS credits
on hand for the tolls."
Via general sector communication, a temporary space station transmits, "Current
riftflow conditions are 2473 light-minutes per second from Galactic
Northnortheast and Slightly Up."
Via general sector communication, Beacon E-02 transmits in a robotic voice,
"Detecting vessel 'Herding Cats.' Welcome to The Belt of Orion."
ftl 285
This rift accelerator requires paying a toll of 7,000,000.00 EAOS credits. Do
you wish to pay this?
[Enter `yes' or `no']
y
You transfer a toll payment to a local rift accelerator.
The computer announces, "Setting course to Asteroid Beacon Alpha 285. Local rift
accelerator with matching vector found."
Something deep inside the starship roars to life as the lights dim sharply.
A wormhole suddenly appears in front of the ship, its edges tinged an unusual
deep purple. Strange undulating shapes are half-visible deep inside it.
A thick undulating mist suddenly seems to rush toward the starship from every
direction, quickly blotting out the stars. Random shapes, some half-familiar,
occasionally form in the mist only to disappear almost immediately.
The computer beeps in an imperative manner and informs you that the starship's
sensors have detected a new location of interest in the riftflow.
The computer beeps in an imperative manner and informs you that the starship's
sensors have detected a new location of interest in the riftflow.
The computer beeps in an imperative manner and informs you that the starship's
sensors have detected a new location of interest in the riftflow.
The mist swirls and obscures your vision. It quickly evaporates, leaving you in
an alien landscape. Tall grassed plains stretch on as far as the eye can see, as
the planet's sun is slowly setting on the horizon.

A formless mist suddenly swirls outside the viewports, then is rapidly sucked
forward into a bright wormhole in front of the ship. The wormhole blinks out of
existence, and the ship is suddenly in normal space.

Via general sector communication, a temporary space station transmits, "Welcome
to Asteroid Beacon Alpha 285. Surrounding space is rich with haulable asteroids
and grade 40 to 60 debris chunks. The occasional salvage op might also be held
here and repair, rearm and recharge facilities are frequently present. Your way
home is home beacon Alpha 286. Fly safe!"

and a thick synthleather bandolier with large pockets. Your face, both eyes, and
neck are left uncovered.

You press your back up against a temporary station with a large precharged
battery module (contributed by Lily Kaise) (attached), an external rift inserter
module (contributed by Business Cats) (attached), a high-power rift accelerator

pushes it towards the open bay door, gradually building momentum, until it
drifts out into empty space.

--
Main Accelerator: Not Aligned
Which heading do you wish to align the main rift accelerator to? The given
vector and its reverse vector will be valid for rift acceleration. This can be
done only once.

-78.0? This cannot be changed once set.

vector of 224.99999958864, 78.0.

The computer announces, "Setting course to Home Beacon Alpha 286. Local rift
accelerator with matching vector found."
Something deep inside the starship roars to life as the lights dim sharply.
A wormhole suddenly appears in front of the ship, its edges tinged an unusual
deep purple. Strange undulating shapes are half-visible deep inside it.
A thick undulating mist suddenly seems to rush toward the starship from every
direction, quickly blotting out the stars. Random shapes, some half-familiar,
occasionally form in the mist only to disappear almost immediately.
The starship has left a unique area of space.
The computer beeps in an imperative manner and informs you that the starship's
sensors have detected a new location of interest in the riftflow.
The formless shifting void gradually acquires a regular crest and fall until,
after several moments, you suddenly realize you are on a wide expanse of ocean.
Tall wooden masts creak above you, and white canvas sails snap in the breeze.

Providence Station shines brightly in the dark, one of the few stations that
bothers to illuminate its outer hull. The gleaming hull of the station is bathed
with bright white floodlights.
New Earth rotates through space before you, a startingly verdant planet, colored
in greens and blues with pure white clouds.
stop
You press a button to cancel the current autopilot program.
Via general sector communication, New Earth transmits, "Hello there, Herding
Cats! Welcome to home space!"
ftl accord
A handful of lonely beacons watch over this area of space, their lights glowing
palely in the dark, surrounded by tendrils of drifting dust and debris.
A planet once existed here, until it was destroyed by the Outsiders. Now only
large chunks of the planet remain, still drifting slowly away from each other,
with clouds of debris filling the sector.
A circular space station dominates this sector, made of darkened metal
reinforced against attack. By the look of it, this is probably the most heavily
armored station in human space, excepting The Torus. This is the heart of the
Accord of Free Worlds.

allowed to operate on planets or large space stations. A computer interface
provides access to buying and selling on the marketplace, and a large chute
underneath it allows items to emerge as they are delivered via wormhole.

sit chair
You sit down on a gray leather captain's chair.
From a phone-based holoemitter: The image of President Warren Garner appears. He
says, "It's clear that the civilian pilot program has suffered from a lack of
discipline and leadership. Perhaps we asked too much of civilians, who do not
have the benefit of the intensive training our military receive. Regardless,
it's clear that the actions of the civilian corps, from engaging in human
trafficking to embarrassing us before the Mutuality Council to indulging in
conspiracies about deep space cults, leave us with little choice but to continue
the gradual cessation of the civilian program. Our gap in expeditions will be
made up by a well-equipped, well-trained branch of the navy."
From a phone-based holoemitter: The image changes to show Eric Best. He shakes
his head, then gestures animatedly as he says, "It's all nonsense. The only
problems our civilians have faced is being too worried about what others think
of us. Who cares what the Mutuality or the League think of us? We must make
progress on our own terms. And one thing is clear, the civilian pilot program
has always had tremendous success in bringing in new resources and creating new
wealth, something no branch of the navy is able to match. This idea of
eliminating our civilian pilots is terrible."
From a phone-based holoemitter: The image changes to that of Kaisa Rebane.
"These answers are both extremes. I see no reason why the civilian pilot program
can't continue in much the same way as it is now. Yes, there have been many
unfortunate incidents, and we will have to take care and look closely at the
program before deciding whether to open it to new applicants again. And, yes,
the pilots we have now would certainly need to begin showing some leadership.
But Mr. Best is right, the program brings in incredible wealth, and its
continuation is essential to the health of the economy until a suitable private
sector equivalent emerges."
From a phone-based holoemitter: The image fades into that of the newscaster once
again, who remarks, "The moderator then raised the issue of relations with the
Mutuality, which still have yet to be normalized, which resulted in a fiery
exchange."
From a phone-based holoemitter: President Garner says, "We should strive to have
good relationships with all of our neighbors, and the Mutuality certainly
qualify, in travel time if not in distance. Perhaps when the civilian pilot
program is discontinued, we can convince them to engage with our state
department rather than the civilian corps, and our diplomats can work on
rebuilding that relationship."
[AEU | 10: Conquest Status] An AEU pilot corps liaison transmits, "We almost
have both performance goals in hand! Keep pushing!"
From a phone-based holoemitter: Mr. Best shakes his head. "Waste of time. Look,
they want nothing to do with us, so why waste time bowing and scraping to them?
We put our tax money into the Accord, tax money that gets spent on defending
Mutuality space, sending rift probes with classified technology to bizarre cult
societies, and even repairing space stations belonging to a completely different
species. What do we get out of that? What have they given us? No more. We need
to look to our own borders. If we empower our civilian program and our navy,
with MILITARY technology, then we'll do great. Things are very bad right now,
but we can do great."
[AEU | 1: Alliance Communication] Kim Saunders transmits, "With their
statements, both Garner and Best have made up my mind, I think. Garner will get
us out of a job. Best will keep us in it at the cost of everything I believe in,
cooperation, trying to fix relations with the mutuality regardless how bleak it
all looks. I guess my voting choice is clear, but other choices are not so."
From a phone-based holoemitter: Ms. Rebane responds, "I agree with Mr. Best that
we need to spend our tax money more wisely. Spending less on the Accord
initiative would allow for tax cuts across the board, kicking our economy back
into high gear and giving us the funding we need to subsidize private sector
solutions for bringing in new resources. This so-called Expeditionary Force
would be an expensive boondoggle. But I have to disagree with this blind
empowerment of the civilian corps. A measured, considered approach is best, and
in time, again, I would like to see that program transition to a private
initiative, out of the hands of the government."
From a phone-based holoemitter: The newscaster smiles tightly as she reappears
on the screen. "A stark choice stands before the AEU in regards to its space
program as well as many other issues. Election Day is on Tuesday, November 1st,
less than two weeks away, and the polls are still tight!"
From a phone-based holoemitter: "That's all we have time for today. This has
been the Interstellar Politics Hour, only on ISNN!"

ftl acord
"acord" does not match any known sector.
ftl accord
A handful of lonely beacons watch over this area of space, their lights glowing
palely in the dark, surrounded by tendrils of drifting dust and debris.
A planet once existed here, until it was destroyed by the Outsiders. Now only
large chunks of the planet remain, still drifting slowly away from each other,
with clouds of debris filling the sector.
A circular space station dominates this sector, made of darkened metal
reinforced against attack. By the look of it, this is probably the most heavily
armored station in human space, excepting The Torus. This is the heart of the
Accord of Free Worlds.
Via general sector communication, Accord of Free Worlds Command transmits,
"Hello, Kalliste. Welcome to Accord space."

Subject: Re: Rift repairing tools and cases.
Author: lunarfang
Posted: Fri Oct 21 19:57:03 2016 UTC
--
but you'd have to take them out to use them. since you don't type use to use
them, you type repair. verses the tool cases and what not, where you can type
use band, for those tool things, and choose from there. I see them more as
gadgets verses eng tools. they may repair the ship, but both internally and
externally, so the code is a bit different I think. you're not directly
affecting a percentage like your hull or turrets, or energy. at least not a
number we can see. at any rate.

Subject: Re: Sketches
Author: autumnrain
Posted: Thu Oct 20 02:25:28 2016 UTC
--
I truly admire those with enough sight to be artistic. I am unable to enjoy the
sketches so raved about in this thread, but I hope the artist does keep up the
good work and if I had the eyesight, I'm sure I would enjoy your work as well. I
have always wanted to make my own art but sadly, no matter how well I try to
visualize things enough to put them on paper or sculpt them in clay, people have
a difficult time identifying what I've drawn or sculpted, which kind of doesn't
feel so great, so I kind of gave up on the whole artsy thing several years ago.
So keep drawing, keep sculpting, whatever you do.
--

unimportant as Mr. Best thinks, but not as important as the other two seem to
believe."
[AEU | 1: Alliance Communication] Kim Saunders transmits, "Well, I am not really
surprised. Best keeps us in our job, and even last year you stated in a meeting
that you did not really see the need of better relations with other alliances."
[AEU | 1: Alliance Communication] Lily Kaise transmits, "Ather I believe you
have unamymous or nearly so agreement on that."
[General Communication] Akemi Bando transmits, "Does anyone know what Mr. Best
meant when he was talking about military technology?"
[General Communication] Aisling the Fox transmits, "Assume militarizing civilian
fleet. Which I take means focusing on warships."
[AEU | 10: Conquest Status] An AEU pilot corps liaison transmits, "Let's keep it
up! That second performance goal is nearly ours!"
[AEU | 1: Alliance Communication] Kim Saunders transmits, "Well, I stand by what
I said earlier, I rather give up this job that I love fighting for what I feel
is right, than continue to support this isolationism the AEU seems to have
fallen victim to. No, we are not that wonderful pilot core we may have once
been, and no, I do not feel we can afford an atitude of we are great and what
other alliances think can be ignored."
power

from the various starship systems.

is now fully mapped and lined with beacons.

2
A pair of odd-colored stars, one green and one blue, mark this curious area of
space. The sensors are picking up odd bits of noise that the ship's computer
insists on trying to convert to audio. Once in a while, something that could
almost sound like a word emerges from a burst of static.
The computer reports that in-sector beacons are transmitting the following:
e2qa`D31!c$(h13(blV59?`{f>P)1~}"|H)10SI+
This area of space is within the green belt of the nearest star, but there are
no life-bearing planets here. Instead there is merely an odd cluster of space
stations of unknown origin.
The sensor noise is much worse here, with a constant dark, gutteral snarling
sound emanating from the ship's speakers. It almost sounds like a language, but
it's nothing you've ever heard before, and the ship's computer cannot pinpoint a
source.
Via general sector communication, a temporary space station transmits, "Hello
pilots, as you travel to the bubble or one of our two asteroid hauling stations,
remember to stay safe, keep a check on your charge and please have EAOS credits
on hand for the tolls."
Via general sector communication, a temporary space station transmits, "Current
riftflow conditions are 2210 light-minutes per second from Galactic Southwest
and Slightly Down."
Via general sector communication, Beacon E-02 transmits in a robotic voice,
"Detecting vessel 'Kalliste.' Welcome to The Belt of Orion."

ftl orion

[1] The Shoulder of Orion (Unclaimed)

2
A pair of odd-colored stars, one green and one blue, mark this curious area of
space. The sensors are picking up odd bits of noise that the ship's computer
insists on trying to convert to audio. Once in a while, something that could
almost sound like a word emerges from a burst of static.
The computer reports that in-sector beacons are transmitting the following:
"qb#HwCIoE>uLm\[]Gn]5"9D2^n6}"a:U*s7}t;Y
This area of space is within the green belt of the nearest star, but there are
no life-bearing planets here. Instead there is merely an odd cluster of space
stations of unknown origin.
The sensor noise is much worse here, with a constant dark, gutteral snarling
sound emanating from the ship's speakers. It almost sounds like a language, but
it's nothing you've ever heard before, and the ship's computer cannot pinpoint a
source.
Via general sector communication, a temporary space station transmits, "Hello
pilots, as you travel to the bubble or one of our two asteroid hauling stations,
remember to stay safe, keep a check on your charge and please have EAOS credits
on hand for the tolls."
Via general sector communication, a temporary space station transmits, "Current
riftflow conditions are 2232 light-minutes per second from Galactic Southwest
and Slightly Down."
Via general sector communication, Beacon E-02 transmits in a robotic voice,
"Detecting vessel 'Kalliste.' Welcome to The Belt of Orion."

ftl accord
The computer reports that the two-person medium transport "Money Maker" has
docked with League Xenological Salvage Processing Debris-Burning Message Beacon.
A handful of lonely beacons watch over this area of space, their lights glowing
palely in the dark, surrounded by tendrils of drifting dust and debris.
A planet once existed here, until it was destroyed by the Outsiders. Now only
large chunks of the planet remain, still drifting slowly away from each other,
with clouds of debris filling the sector.
A circular space station dominates this sector, made of darkened metal
reinforced against attack. By the look of it, this is probably the most heavily
armored station in human space, excepting The Torus. This is the heart of the
Accord of Free Worlds.
Via general sector communication, Accord of Free Worlds Command transmits,
"Hello, Kalliste. Welcome to Accord space."

This is a tank for holding critters!
It is filled with water.
It is open.
Inside it you see a white plastic undersea castle and a plastic wrecked AEU
Soothsayer.
It appears that there are ample food particles in the water.
A short violet soft-bodied creature with many claw-tipped tentacles, a small
sleek speckled amber aquatic creature with rounded fins, a large sleek speckled
amber aquatic creature with pentagonal fins, a small sleek speckled white
aquatic creature with frilled fins, a large sleek speckled crimson aquatic
creature with pentagonal fins, a small sleek speckled violet aquatic creature
with pentagonal fins, a small sleek speckled amber aquatic creature with
hexagonal fins, a large sleek speckled crimson aquatic creature with pentagonal
fins, and a large sleek speckled amber aquatic creature with rounded fins are
living in it.
That's nine creatures, and the tank could probably safely hold six more.

streamlined control board sits before the starmap, with prominent indicators for
lock status and weapon readiness. Control boards for the ship's weaponry are off
to either side, to be pulled into place at a moment's notice. The status lights

that the ship is in a garage.

A pair of odd-colored stars, one green and one blue, mark this curious area of
space. The sensors are picking up odd bits of noise that the ship's computer
insists on trying to convert to audio. Once in a while, something that could
almost sound like a word emerges from a burst of static.
The computer reports that in-sector beacons are transmitting the following:
a/`s9iAB!;~f<?X-DxV|*>A&)a]i0K/s~9i3e@]/
This area of space is within the green belt of the nearest star, but there are
no life-bearing planets here. Instead there is merely an odd cluster of space
stations of unknown origin.
You stumble, then fall heavily to the floor.
(3 seconds roundtime.)
The sensor noise is much worse here, with a constant dark, gutteral snarling
sound emanating from the ship's speakers. It almost sounds like a language, but
it's nothing you've ever heard before, and the ship's computer cannot pinpoint a
source.
Via general sector communication, a temporary space station transmits, "Hello
pilots, as you travel to the bubble or one of our two asteroid hauling stations,
remember to stay safe, keep a check on your charge and please have EAOS credits
on hand for the tolls."
Via general sector communication, a temporary space station transmits, "Current
riftflow conditions are 2247 light-minutes per second from Galactic Southwest
and Slightly Down."

A planet once existed here, until it was destroyed by the Outsiders. Now only

A circular space station dominates this sector, made of darkened metal
reinforced against attack. By the look of it, this is probably the most heavily
armored station in human space, excepting The Torus. This is the heart of the
Accord of Free Worlds.

[New Earth; Pilot Lounge]
This roomy, circular lounge sits on the very lip of the landing pad outside,
with half of it suspended over the water below. Large transparisteel windows
overlook the ocean at one end and afford a great view of the landing pad at the
other, the material tinting itself automatically when needed. The walls, tables,
and floor are gleaming white lucite, kept immaculately clean by tiny drones that
zip around with automated efficiency. A row of couches face toward the windows,
leaving a relatively open section in the middle of the room. The news broadcast
flickers across the surface of each sleek white table to keep the pilots
informed of the latest goings-on. A stairway towards the back of the room has
its door open and bears a sign reading 'Garage'.
You see a semi-circular bar, a public holovid, a brightly-lit candy vending
machine, a shiny chrome trash bin, and Kulta the little black CatBot here.
Jonathon Glythmon, Evenia Callseah, and Lily Kaise are standing here.

l emmett
Emmett Lee
He appears to be 25 years old. He is about five feet and ten inches tall and has
tan skin. His body is athletic with bony hips and well-muscled calves. He has
rounded shoulders and a muscular chest. His face is round and handsome, with a
pointed nose and dimpled chin. His lips are full and light-colored and
occasionally part to reveal a set of white teeth. Beneath a set of thin
eyebrows, his eyes are blue and almond-shaped. His very short, bristly hair is
blonde and neatly combed. He has short pale fingernails. He has a past injury on
his right hand.
 He is wearing a soft blue long-sleeved shirt with a buttoned-down collar, a
sleek gold watch with sapphire accents, a black leather belt with a square gold
buckle, a pair of relaxed fit blue jeans, and a pair of black canvas sneakers
illustrated with cartoonish paintings of gold spider monkeys. He is also wearing
a glowing neon blue ring, a glowing neon blue ring, a glowing neon blue ring, a
glowing neon blue ring, a Rat Killer keychain, a metallic gold metachannel FTL
communicator, a portable newsfeed aggregator, a message board reader, and a
tiger-striped backpack. His head, face, both eyes, neck, left wrist, and both
hands are left uncovered.
He is carrying nothing.
Lily Kaise gives Emmett Lee a thumbs up!

l
[Starship "Critical Strike"; Control Room]
The control room is the hub of every starship. Large metal conduits protect
thick bundles of wires carrying information from every part of the ship to this
one location. A large transparisteel viewport provides a view out the front of
the ship, but experienced pilots in space will have eyes only for the large
starmap dominating the right side of the room. Standing before the viewport is
the main control board, providing essential functions like the shipwide power
lever and alert status. Secondary control boards can be pulled up and folded
back to provide a working surface, or pulled down from recesses overhead as
needed. Though the room is spacious enough for a few others to sit or stand, the
entire architecture of the room is built around the small space before the
control board and the person who will stand there: the starship's pilot. Lights
overhead indicate that the ship is on green status. Looking through the windows,
you see that the ship is in space.
You see a decoy beacon launcher, a steel plaque engraved with the phrase
"Reminder: This ship is equipped with a sensor dampening array.", a wormhole
drive tracer, a black leather captain's chair, a dark red leather captain's
chair, and a black leather sofa here.
You can go south and out.

A pair of odd-colored stars, one green and one blue, mark this curious area of
space. The sensors are picking up odd bits of noise that the ship's computer
insists on trying to convert to audio. Once in a while, something that could
almost sound like a word emerges from a burst of static.
The computer reports that in-sector beacons are transmitting the following:
7:TE/|[pDSp@xYHfGGNQZYBX{>0x4NTeHBSBO?jw
This area of space is within the green belt of the nearest star, but there are
no life-bearing planets here. Instead there is merely an odd cluster of space
stations of unknown origin.
Small clinks of metal come from the hull of the ship as it's being repaired.
The sensor noise is much worse here, with a constant dark, gutteral snarling
sound emanating from the ship's speakers. It almost sounds like a language, but
it's nothing you've ever heard before, and the ship's computer cannot pinpoint a
source.

l
[Starship "Critical Strike"; Control Room]
The control room is the hub of every starship. Large metal conduits protect
thick bundles of wires carrying information from every part of the ship to this
one location. A large transparisteel viewport provides a view out the front of
the ship, but experienced pilots in space will have eyes only for the large
starmap dominating the right side of the room. Standing before the viewport is
the main control board, providing essential functions like the shipwide power
lever and alert status. Secondary control boards can be pulled up and folded
back to provide a working surface, or pulled down from recesses overhead as
needed. Though the room is spacious enough for a few others to sit or stand, the
entire architecture of the room is built around the small space before the
control board and the person who will stand there: the starship's pilot. Lights
overhead indicate that the ship is on green status. Looking through the windows,
you see that the ship is in space.
You see a decoy beacon launcher, a steel plaque engraved with the phrase
"Reminder: This ship is equipped with a sensor dampening array.", a wormhole
drive tracer, a black leather captain's chair, a dark red leather captain's
chair, and a black leather sofa here.
You can go south and out.

You sit down on a black leather captain's chair.

of confirmed hits. Other gunners: Evenia Callseah with 31.6% of confirmed hits
and Emmett Lee with 26.3% of confirmed hits."
The computer reports that the executioner-class escort "Escort Delta Zzormr" has
launched a rescue pod.
The computer reports that it has collected an alien liquid-filled transparisteel
panel, an Outsider sensor construct of some kind, a portion of a wormhole drive,
five of an interior panel, six of an unidentifiable starship component, and six
of an intact hull plate from an exploding starship.
You earn 5,000,000.00 AEU credits for a successful beacon drop, plus a kill
bonus of 3,375,000.00 AEU credits, plus an enemy magnitude bonus of 1,000,000.00
AEU credits.

space. The sensors are picking up odd bits of noise that the ship's computer

almost sound like a word emerges from a burst of static.

This area of space is within the green belt of the nearest star, but there are
no life-bearing planets here. Instead there is merely an odd cluster of space
stations of unknown origin.

source.

A pair of odd-colored stars, one green and one blue, mark this curious area of
space. The sensors are picking up odd bits of noise that the ship's computer
insists on trying to convert to audio. Once in a while, something that could
almost sound like a word emerges from a burst of static.
The computer reports that in-sector beacons are transmitting the following:
R,NF|jHN}F.Us?#>SM2<\zW'tt<x=x'~Ccb5'f~u
This area of space is within the green belt of the nearest star, but there are
no life-bearing planets here. Instead there is merely an odd cluster of space
stations of unknown origin.
A Tardick lizard named Asteria, perched on Lily Kaise's shoulder, blinks its
yellow eyes slowly, utterly indifferent to its surroundings.
The sensor noise is much worse here, with a constant dark, gutteral snarling
sound emanating from the ship's speakers. It almost sounds like a language, but
it's nothing you've ever heard before, and the ship's computer cannot pinpoint a
source.

Lily Kaise
She appears to be 27 years old. She is about five feet and two inches tall and
has fair skin. Her body is thin with attractively curved hips and shapely
calves. She has slender shoulders and slightly larger than average breasts. Her
face is oval and pretty, with a delicate nose and understated chin. Her lips are
lovely and blush pink and occasionally part to reveal a set of pretty teeth.
Beneath a set of arched eyebrows, her eyes are blue-green and almond-shaped. Her
waist-length, straight hair is pale honey blonde and swept up into a thick fall
of loose curls down her back. She has oval pink fingernails.
A small enameled cerulean blue dragonfly pierces her left earlobe and a small
enameled cerulean blue dragonfly pierces her right earlobe.

print, a pair of tight light blue denim jeans with a small dark-red 'XX'
embroidered on the back left pocket, and a pair of sparkly white leather clogs.
She is also wearing an orange and white blessed prayer bracelet around her
wrist, a slender bracelet of tiny tinkling silver bells around her wrist, a neon
purple wrist-mounted chronometer, a solid silver ring engraved with dragonflies,
a delicate ring of silver wire and small purple amethyst crystals, a metallic
gold touch einrophone in a metallic purple reinforced plastic phone holster, a

lizard snuggly labeled 'Asteria', and a Tardick lizard named Asteria perched on
her shoulder. Her head, face, both eyes, neck, both wrists, and both hands are
left uncovered.
